section.section:
v1() v1Ramsey\Uuid Ramsey\Uuidv1
v1 ( $node = null , ?int $clockSeq = null )
Returns a version 1 (time-based) UUID from a host ID, sequence number, and the current time
Paramètres
Hexadecimal | int | string | null$node
A 48-bit number representing the hardware address; this number may be represented as an integer or a hexadecimal string
int$clockSeq
A 14-bit number used to help avoid duplicates that could arise when the clock is set backwards in time or if the node ID changes
Renvoie
non-empty-string Version 1 UUID as a string
Voici le graphe d'appel pour cette fonction :

section.title: v2()
section.para: Returns a version 2 (DCE Security) UUID from a local domain, local identifier, host ID, clock sequence, and the current time

entry.para: The local domain to use when generating bytes, according to DCE Security
The local identifier for the given domain; this may be a UID or GID on POSIX systems, if the local domain is person or group, or it may be a site-defined identifier if the local domain is org
A 48-bit number representing the hardware address
A 14-bit number used to help avoid duplicates that could arise when the clock is set backwards in time or if the node ID changes

formalpara.title: Renvoie
formalpara.para: non-empty-string Version 2 UUID as a string

section.section:
v3() v3Ramsey\Uuid Ramsey\Uuidv3
v3 ( $ns, string $name)
Returns a version 3 (name-based) UUID based on the MD5 hash of a namespace ID and a name
Paramètres
string | UuidInterface$ns
The namespace (must be a valid UUID)
Renvoie
non-empty-string Version 3 UUID as a string
@psalm-pure note: changing the internal factory is an edge case not covered by purity invariants, but under constant factory setups, this method operates in functionally pure manners Voici le graphe d'appel pour cette fonction :

v4() v4Ramsey\Uuid Ramsey\Uuidv4
v4 ( )
Returns a version 4 (random) UUID
Renvoie
non-empty-string Version 4 UUID as a string
Voici le graphe d'appel pour cette fonction :

v5() v5Ramsey\Uuid Ramsey\Uuidv5
v5 ( $ns, string $name)
Returns a version 5 (name-based) UUID based on the SHA-1 hash of a namespace ID and a name
Paramètres
string | UuidInterface$ns
The namespace (must be a valid UUID)
Renvoie
non-empty-string Version 5 UUID as a string
@psalm-pure note: changing the internal factory is an edge case not covered by purity invariants, but under constant factory setups, this method operates in functionally pure manners Voici le graphe d'appel pour cette fonction :

v6() v6Ramsey\Uuid Ramsey\Uuidv6
v6 (?Hexadecimal $node = null , ?int $clockSeq = null )
Returns a version 6 (ordered-time) UUID from a host ID, sequence number, and the current time
Paramètres
Hexadecimal | null$node
A 48-bit number representing the hardware address
int$clockSeq
A 14-bit number used to help avoid duplicates that could arise when the clock is set backwards in time or if the node ID changes
Renvoie
non-empty-string Version 6 UUID as a string
Voici le graphe d'appel pour cette fonction :

section.title: DeprecatedUuidMethodsTrait
section.para: This trait encapsulates deprecated methods for ramsey/uuid; this trait and its methods will be removed in ramsey/uuid 5.0.0.
